intro: Paullinia chocoensis, commonly known as the Chocó wax apple, is a tropical plant native to the rainforests of Colombia and Ecuador. It is a member of the Sapindaceae family and is characterized by its large, waxy, yellow or orange fruits that resemble apples. The plant typically grows as a shrub or small tree, reaching heights of up to 5 meters. Its leaves are simple, alternate, and often have a distinctive reddish or purplish hue. The fruit is not only ornamental but also has traditional uses in local cultures.
